item.title: Fine‐Tuning Gramicidin S: How δ‐Phenylproline Affects Turns and Interaction with Membrane
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, EarlyView.
item.dc:description:
Introducing a phenyl group at the 5‐cis position of proline in gramicidin S markedly alters its conformation. This substitution induces a double γ‐turn that disrupts the native β‐sheet and hinders membrane insertion.
The incorporation of a phenyl ring at the 5‐position of proline markedly influences the conformation and membrane interactions of gramicidin S. Herein, the structural and biophysical consequences of introducing cis‐5‐phenyl‐L‐proline into gramicidin S are computationally investigated, with a particular focus on its conformational behavior and lipid bilayer interactions. Using a homochiral model dipeptide, it is shown that cis‐5‐phenyl‐L‐proline promotes the formation of a double γ‐turn, significantly altering the peptide's folding characteristics. This conformational bias is transferred to the modified gramicidin S scaffold, where it perturbs the native amphipathic balance and results in less favorable membrane interactions. These findings underscore the pivotal role of proline‐derived modifications in shaping the structural and functional properties of cyclic peptides and offer valuable insights into how targeted substitutions can modulate peptide–membrane interactions.
item.content:encoded:
Introducing a phenyl group at the 5-cis position of proline in gramicidin S markedly alters its conformation. This substitution induces a double γ-turn that disrupts the native β-sheet and hinders membrane insertion.


The incorporation of a phenyl ring at the 5-position of proline markedly influences the conformation and membrane interactions of gramicidin S. Herein, the structural and biophysical consequences of introducing cis-5-phenyl-L-proline into gramicidin S are computationally investigated, with a particular focus on its conformational behavior and lipid bilayer interactions. Using a homochiral model dipeptide, it is shown that cis-5-phenyl-L-proline promotes the formation of a double γ-turn, significantly altering the peptide's folding characteristics. This conformational bias is transferred to the modified gramicidin S scaffold, where it perturbs the native amphipathic balance and results in less favorable membrane interactions. These findings underscore the pivotal role of proline-derived modifications in shaping the structural and functional properties of cyclic peptides and offer valuable insights into how targeted substitutions can modulate peptide–membrane interactions.

item.source: Wiley-Online-Library: European Journal of Organic Chemistry: Table of Contents
item.title: Metal‐Free Four‐Component Strategy to Access Thioether‐Derived Imidazo[1,2‐a]pyridines and Imidazo[2,1‐b]thiazoles
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, EarlyView.
item.dc:description:
A unique four‐component approach for constructing imidazole motifs and enabling sulfuration from simple chemical feedstocks leads to a diverse range of thioether‐derived imidazo[1,2‐a]pyridines and imidazo[2,1‐b]thiazoles with moderate‐to‐good yields.
A metal‐free construction of thioether‐derived imidazo[1,2‐a]pyridines and imidazo[2,1‐b]thiazoles holds significant potential in medicinal chemistry. However, the exploration of multicomponent synthesis using simple chemical feedstocks has not been thoroughly investigated. A new four‐component strategy involving base‐mediated annulation and I2‐promoted sulfenylation has been developed, utilizing readily accessible α‐bromoketones, 2‐aminopyridines, and alkyl bromides, with sodium thiosulfate (Na2S2O3.5H2O) serving as the sulfur source. Consequently, this approach effectively produces a series of imidazo[1,2‐a]pyridine‐derived thioethers in moderate‐to‐good yields, showcasing a wide substrate scope with good functional group tolerance and compatibility. Furthermore, the multicomponent protocol has been successfully extended to synthesize sulfenyl‐derived imidazo[2,1‐b]thiazoles in acceptable yields using the corresponding 2‐aminothiazole. Importantly, metal‐free multicomponent reactions have been successfully employed on a Gram scale in open air, and a plausible mechanism has also been proposed based on existing results.

item.title: Synthesis of 3‐Aminotetrahydrofurans and Tetrahydrofuro[2,3‐b]furans by Gold‐Catalyzed Cyclization of 3‐Aminopent‐4‐yn‐1‐ols
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, EarlyView.
item.dc:description:
A gold‐catalyzed reaction of 3‐aminopent‐4‐yn‐1‐ols is described. 2‐Arylidene‐3‐aminotetrahydrofurans are synthesized via intramolecular nucleophilic cyclization of the hydroxy group with the activated alkyne. When the reaction is carried out with phenols as an additional nucleophile and Sc(OTf)3 as an activating reagent, tetrahydrofuro[2,3‐b]benzofurans are obtained.
A gold‐catalyzed reaction of 3‐aminopent‐4‐yn‐1‐ols is described. 2‐Arylidene‐3‐aminotetrahydrofurans are synthesized via intramolecular nucleophilic cyclization of the hydroxy group with the activated alkyne. When the reaction is carried out with phenols as an additional nucleophile and Sc(OTf)3 as an activating reagent, tetrahydrofuro[2,3‐b]benzofurans are obtained. The reaction proceeds via a deaminative nucleophilic substitution of 3‐aminopent‐4‐yn‐1‐ols with phenols, followed by a successive intramolecular cyclization of the two hydroxy groups with the activated alkyne. When 1,3‐dicarbonyl compounds are used as the nucleophile, the corresponding substituted tetrahydrofuro[2,3‐b]furans are formed. To further understand the nature of this reaction, the intramolecular nucleophilic addition of alkynyl diol intermediate with gold complex is investigated as a model substrate using DFT calculations.
item.content:encoded:

When the reaction is carried out with phenols as an additional nucleophile and Sc(OTf)3 as an activating reagent, tetrahydrofuro[2,3-b]benzofurans are obtained.


A gold-catalyzed reaction of 3-aminopent-4-yn-1-ols is described. 2-Arylidene-3-aminotetrahydrofurans are synthesized via intramolecular nucleophilic cyclization of the hydroxy group with the activated alkyne. When the reaction is carried out with phenols as an additional nucleophile and Sc(OTf)3 as an activating reagent, tetrahydrofuro[2,3-b]benzofurans are obtained. The reaction proceeds via a deaminative nucleophilic substitution of 3-aminopent-4-yn-1-ols with phenols, followed by a successive intramolecular cyclization of the two hydroxy groups with the activated alkyne. When 1,3-dicarbonyl compounds are used as the nucleophile, the corresponding substituted tetrahydrofuro[2,3-b]furans are formed. To further understand the nature of this reaction, the intramolecular nucleophilic addition of alkynyl diol intermediate with gold complex is investigated as a model substrate using DFT calculations.

item.title: Visible Light‐Induced Three‐Component Synthesis of S‐Aryl Dithiocarbamates via Electron Donor–Acceptor Complex Using Arylselenonium Salts
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, EarlyView.
item.dc:description:
A novel visible‐light driven one‐pot multicomponent reactions of aryl selenonium salts, CS2, and amines for preparation of S‐aryl dithiocarbamates has been developed.
A multicomponent reaction for the efficient synthesis of S‐aryl dithiocarbamates from arylselenonium salts, CS2, and amines under visible light irradiation is demonstrated. This protocol enables straightforward construction of C(sp2)S bonds via CSe bond cleavage and allows the synthesis of diverse aryl sulfides. This three‐component process proceeds without any photocatalyst, exogenous single‐electron transfer (SET) mediator, or additional oxidant. Remarkably, this developed strategy exhibits the advantages of mild conditions, broad substrate scope, and operational simplicity. Furthermore, the byproduct dibenzoselenophene can be recovered to provide new arylselenonium salts. Mechanistic studies support the method involving a photoinduced EDA complex.
item.content:encoded:
A novel visible-light driven one-pot multicomponent reactions of aryl selenonium salts, CS2, and amines for preparation of S-aryl dithiocarbamates has been developed.


A multicomponent reaction for the efficient synthesis of S-aryl dithiocarbamates from arylselenonium salts, CS2, and amines under visible light irradiation is demonstrated. This protocol enables straightforward construction of C(sp2)S bonds via CSe bond cleavage and allows the synthesis of diverse aryl sulfides. This three-component process proceeds without any photocatalyst, exogenous single-electron transfer (SET) mediator, or additional oxidant. Remarkably, this developed strategy exhibits the advantages of mild conditions, broad substrate scope, and operational simplicity. Furthermore, the byproduct dibenzoselenophene can be recovered to provide new arylselenonium salts. Mechanistic studies support the method involving a photoinduced EDA complex.
item.dc:creator: Yisong Tang, Yilin Tang, Congjin Yang

item.title: Stereoselective Synthesis of Unsymmetrical 3,3‐Diarylpropenals by a Suzuki–Miyaura Reaction of (Z)‐3‐Aryl‐3‐Chloropropenal Intermediates
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, EarlyView.
item.dc:description:
An efficient Suzuki coupling‐type procedure is developed to stereospecifically prepare unsymmetrical 3,3‐diarylpropenals in high yield. Mild oxidation of the 3,3‐diarylpropenoic acids and further lactonization to form 4‐arylcoumarins have been achieved. A variety of 4‐arylcoumarins are synthesized via this route with excellent stereochemical purity.
Using (Z)‐3‐aryl‐3‐chloropropenals, this study has developed an efficient route for the stereoselective synthesis of unsymmetrical 3,3‐diarylpropenals in high yield with very good retention of stereochemistry. Consequently, this study has found an efficient route for the stereoselective synthesis of 3,3‐diarylpropenoic acids, which are precursors to 4‐arylcoumarins. The Suzuki–Miyaura coupling of (Z)‐3‐aryl‐3‐chloropropenals with arylboronic acid derivatives yields unsymmetric 3,3‐diarylpropenals in high yields with excellent retention of stereochemistry. These 3,3‐diarylpropenals are then oxidized to the corresponding acrylic acids and lactonized to form 4‐arylcoumarins. The lactonization reaction consistently occurs with the aryl group that is cis to the acid group, that is, with the aryl group that is introduced in the Suzuki coupling step. Thus, the stereochemical retention of the Suzuki–Miyaura coupling step results in the ability to make a diverse catalog of 4‐arylcoumarins with complete stereoselective control. A variety of 4‐arylcoumarins are synthesized via this route with several different aryl substituents giving good yields and excellent stereochemical purity.
item.content:encoded:

A variety of 4-arylcoumarins are synthesized via this route with excellent stereochemical purity.

A variety of 4-arylcoumarins are synthesized via this route with several different aryl substituents giving good yields and excellent stereochemical purity.

item.title: A Chiron Approach to the Practical and Scalable Synthesis of the β3‐Adrenergic Receptor Agonist Vibegron
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, EarlyView.
item.dc:description:
A scalable chiral‐pool‐based synthesis of Vibegron is reported that utilizes 4‐nitro‐D‐phenylalanine and R‐(−)‐mandelic acid as starting materials. The approach offers a concise and stereoselective alternative to conventional asymmetric Evans aldol and dynamic kinetic resolution methods.
A practical and scalable synthesis of the β3‐adrenergic receptor agonist Vibegron has been developed using a streamlined chiral‐pool approach from readily available 4‐nitro‐D‐phenylalanine and (R)‐mandelic acid. The synthesis features a key acid‐catalyzed N‐acyl iminium ion cyclization followed by a highly diastereoselective reduction, enabling efficient construction of the cis‐2,5‐disubstituted pyrrolidine core. Final amidation with a commercially available pyrrolopyrimidine sodium salt furnished Vibegron in excellent overall yield.
item.content:encoded:
A scalable chiral-pool-based synthesis of Vibegron is reported that utilizes 4-nitro-D-phenylalanine and R-(−)-mandelic acid as starting materials. The approach offers a concise and stereoselective alternative to conventional asymmetric Evans aldol and dynamic kinetic resolution methods.


A practical and scalable synthesis of the β 3-adrenergic receptor agonist Vibegron has been developed using a streamlined chiral-pool approach from readily available 4-nitro-D-phenylalanine and (R)-mandelic acid. The synthesis features a key acid-catalyzed N-acyl iminium ion cyclization followed by a highly diastereoselective reduction, enabling efficient construction of the cis-2,5-disubstituted pyrrolidine core. Final amidation with a commercially available pyrrolopyrimidine sodium salt furnished Vibegron in excellent overall yield.

item.title: Ligand‐Free Copper‐Catalyzed Allenylative CP Coupling of Propargylic Acetates with H‐Phosphine Oxides
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, EarlyView.
item.dc:description:
A ligand‐free CuTC‐catalyzed allenylative CP coupling reaction of propargylic acetates with H‐phosphine oxides to yield allenylphosphine oxides is reported, with scope and mechanism discussed.
The extra‐ligand‐free CuTC‐catalyzed CP cross coupling reaction of propargylic acetates with H‐phosphine oxides is reported to afford allenylphosphine oxides. The reaction took place efficiently with diphenylphosphine oxide and electron‐deficient di(4‐fluorophenyl)phosphine oxide, but less effectively with electron‐rich ones such as di(4‐methoxylphenyl)phosphine oxide and dialkylphosphine oxides. H‐phosphine oxides themselves may serve as the ligand.
item.content:encoded:
A ligand-free CuTC-catalyzed allenylative CP coupling reaction of propargylic acetates with H-phosphine oxides to yield allenylphosphine oxides is reported, with scope and mechanism discussed.


The extra-ligand-free CuTC-catalyzed CP cross coupling reaction of propargylic acetates with H-phosphine oxides is reported to afford allenylphosphine oxides. The reaction took place efficiently with diphenylphosphine oxide and electron-deficient di(4-fluorophenyl)phosphine oxide, but less effectively with electron-rich ones such as di(4-methoxylphenyl)phosphine oxide and dialkylphosphine oxides. H-phosphine oxides themselves may serve as the ligand.

item.title: Green Synthesis of Hantzsch Dihydropyridines from Biorenewable Furans Derived from Lignocellulosic Biomass
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, EarlyView.
item.dc:description:
A sustainable methodology is developed for the synthesis of dihydropyridines from furanic aldehydes derived from lignocellulosic biomass, using p‐sulfonic calix[4]arene as a catalyst and microwave irradiation heating. The reaction occurs in the absence of solvents, with short reaction time and satisfactory yields. Twenty one compounds are obtained, seven of which are reported for the first time. Catalyst reusability is demonstrated.
Hantzsch dihydropyridines constitute a class of N‐heterocycles with significant pharmacological and technological applications. Due to their importance, the development of new sustainable synthetic methodologies for producing dihydropyridines is of great interest. This work presents the synthesis of dihydropyridines via the Hantzsch multicomponent reaction. Furanic aldehydes derived from lignocellulosic biomass are used as substrates, and p‐sulfonic acid calix[4]arene (CX4SO3H) is employed as an organocatalyst, under microwave irradiation (MWI). The furanic compounds are reacted with ethyl acetoacetate and ammonium acetate in the presence of 1.0 mol% of CX4SO3H for 10 min at 80 °C under MWI. Twenty one dihydropyridines are synthesized in yields ranging from 43% to 96%. Two dihydropyridines are obtained as crystals suitable for X‐ray diffraction analysis, and their crystallographic data are provided. Moreover, the catalytic system can be reused for seven reaction cycles without significant yield loss. The developed methodology offers numerous advantages. It enables the production of dihydropyridines from renewable substrates via a multicomponent reaction in a single step, with a short reaction time. The process uses a reusable organocatalyst and eliminates the need for solvents or metal catalysts.
item.content:encoded:
A sustainable methodology is developed for the synthesis of dihydropyridines from furanic aldehydes derived from lignocellulosic biomass, using p-sulfonic calix[4]arene as a catalyst and microwave irradiation heating. The reaction occurs in the absence of solvents, with short reaction time and satisfactory yields. Twenty one compounds are obtained, seven of which are reported for the first time. Catalyst reusability is demonstrated.

item.source: Wiley-Online-Library: European Journal of Organic Chemistry: Table of Contents
item.title: Synthesis of the [6‐5‐5‐3] Tetracyclic Core of Cryptotrione
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, EarlyView.
item.dc:description:
A concise approach for the efficient synthesis of the [6‐5‐5‐3] B‐D‐E‐F tetracyclic core of cryptotrione was developed. Key reactions include a transannular aldol reaction followed by an RCM reaction to forge the [6‐5‐5] B‐D‐E tricyclic core and a diastereoselective cyclopropanation to assemble the bicyclo[3.1.0]hexane motif with a side chain.
Cryptotrione, a potent anticancer and structurally complex C35 terpene belonging to the cryptoquinonemethide family, has an unprecedented [6‐6‐6‐5‐5‐3] hexacyclic skeleton with a strained bicyclo[3.1.0]hexane core and [5‐5] spirocyclic moiety. Herein, a concise approach for the synthesis of the [6‐5‐5‐3] B‐D‐E‐F tetracyclic core of cryptotrione without protecting groups is described. The unusual [6‐5‐5] B‐D‐E tricyclic core including a spiro all‐carbon quaternary stereocenter, found in cryptotrione as well as other cryptoquinonemethides, was efficiently constructed by a transannular aldol reaction followed by an RCM reaction. A substrate‐controlled diastereoselective cyclopropanation was used to forge the strained bicyclo[3.1.0]hexane motif with a side chain.
item.content:encoded:

Herein, a concise approach for the synthesis of the [6-5-5-3] B-D-E-F tetracyclic core of cryptotrione without protecting groups is described. The unusual [6-5-5] B-D-E tricyclic core including a spiro all-carbon quaternary stereocenter, found in cryptotrione as well as other cryptoquinonemethides, was efficiently constructed by a transannular aldol reaction followed by an RCM reaction. A substrate-controlled diastereoselective cyclopropanation was used to forge the strained bicyclo[3.1.0]hexane motif with a side chain.

item.source: Wiley-Online-Library: European Journal of Organic Chemistry: Table of Contents
item.title: Photoinduced Cascade Cyclization of Ortho‐Alkynylanilines to Access Dithiocyanated or Selenocyanated Indoles
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, EarlyView.
item.dc:description:
Diverse indole derivatives are obtained by a cascade process involving dithiocyanation or selenocyanation and cyclization of ortho‐alkynylanilines under mild conditions with NH4SCN/KSeCN. Experiments are undertaken to shed light on the radical reaction mechanism and investigate the versatility of the transformation.
A photoinduced cyclization and dithiocyanation/selenocyanation of ortho‐alkynylanilines with NH4SCN/KSeCN provide various dithiocyanated and selenocyanated indoles. The structure of the indole framework is confirmed by single‐crystal X‐ray diffraction. In addition, a series of experiments investigating scale‐up, other starting materials, and radical inhibition/capture are carried out to study the application and reaction process of this cascade system.

item.source: Wiley-Online-Library: European Journal of Organic Chemistry: Table of Contents
item.title: Synthesis of Amphiphilic Naphthalenediimides and Investigation of their Bioimaging Potential in Large Unilamellar Vesicles
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, EarlyView.
item.dc:description:
The efficient synthesis of a small library of nonsymmetrical panchromatic naphthalenediimides is reported. The electron‐donating groups on the aromatic core are varied to tune the fluorophores' photophysical properties . The ability of the dyes to partition and light up inside the lipid bilayer membrane in liposomal models is investigated to evaluate key features for designing compact tracers for cell membrane staining.
New fluorescent probes for bioimaging outlook are constantly required to in‐depth elucidate relevant biochemical processes and macrodomains. Among them, the targeted imaging of cellular membranes is of high importance due to their complex biochemical function. In this work, a small library of amphiphilic core‐substituted 1,4,5,8‐naphthalenediimides (cNDIs) has been synthesized and investigated. This approach aims to evaluate how fluorophores with the same molecular structure and hydrophilic/hydrophobic balance but bearing different small structural moieties, needed to tune their optical features, can stain the lipid bilayer membrane in large unilamellar vesicles (LUVs) as cell membrane models. The photophysical properties and the partition kinetic into different LUVs have been analyzed with respect to the probe structure and the specific photophysical traits related to cNDIs core substitution spanning the whole visible spectrum. The obtained results and preliminary cell imaging analyses represent versatile key data to support the design of new amphiphilic fluorescent sensors for bioimaging.

The ability of the dyes to partition and light up inside the lipid bilayer membrane in liposomal models is investigated to evaluate key features for designing compact tracers for cell membrane staining.

This approach aims to evaluate how fluorophores with the same molecular structure and hydrophilic/hydrophobic balance but bearing different small structural moieties, needed to tune their optical features, can stain the lipid bilayer membrane in large unilamellar vesicles (LUVs) as cell membrane models. The photophysical properties and the partition kinetic into different LUVs have been analyzed with respect to the probe structure and the specific photophysical traits related to cNDIs core substitution spanning the whole visible spectrum. The obtained results and preliminary cell imaging analyses represent versatile key data to support the design of new amphiphilic fluorescent sensors for bioimaging.

item.dc:title: Synthesis of Amphiphilic Naphthalenediimides and Investigation of their Bioimaging Potential in Large Unilamellar Vesicles

item.source: Wiley-Online-Library: European Journal of Organic Chemistry: Table of Contents
item.title: Toward the Synthesis of 3,3‐Difluoro Deaminated Sialic Acid (C3DFKDN)
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, EarlyView.
item.dc:description:
The synthesis of protected C3‐difluoro KDN (C3DFKDN), an unnatural derivative of the sialic acid member, KDN, and key building block for KDN‐based chemical probes, is reported. Its 12‐step synthetic route starts from commercially available methyl d‐mannopyranoside and key steps include a Reformatsky reaction with ethyl bromodifluoroacetate, alkylation with ethyl vinyl ether, and ozonolysis of a terminal double bond.
2‐Keto‐3‐deoxy‐d‐glycero‐d‐galacto‐nononic acid (KDN) is a nine‐carbon monosaccharide of the sialic acid family. As a deaminated analogue of N‐acetylneuraminic acid (Neu5Ac), KDN features a hydroxyl group at C5 instead of an amine. Although present at low levels in mammalian tissues, KDN is abundant in certain tumor cells and pathogens, making it and its processing enzymes attractive targets for understanding biological functions and developing potential therapeutics. Fluorinated carbohydrate derivatives are widely used to probe and modulate carbohydrate‐active enzymes (CAZymes). This report describes the first total synthesis of 3,3‐difluoro KDN (C3DFKDN), a novel fluorinated sialic acid derivative and a key intermediate for designing covalent inhibitors and activity‐based probes targeting KDN‐processing enzymes. Introduction of a C3‐difluoro group prevents elimination side reactions common with monofluorinated sialic acid analogues. Two synthetic strategies are explored: 1) Coupling a pyranose precursor with a difluorinated alkyne bromide followed by oxidation and 2) incorporation of a difluoroacetate building block via a Reformatsky‐type reaction. The latter approach proves more effective, affording protected C3DFKDN in an overall yield of 3.7% over 12 steps from methyl α‐d‐mannopyranoside. This work establishes methodology for the synthesis of C3‐difluorinated sialic acids and provides a foundation for developing fluorinated probes and inhibitors of KDN‐related enzymatic pathways.

item.source: Wiley-Online-Library: European Journal of Organic Chemistry: Table of Contents
item.title: Introduction of Structural Diversity at the C2 Position of Unsaturated Iminosugars through Palladium‐Catalyzed Cross‐Coupling Reactions
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, EarlyView.
item.dc:description:
To increase the structural diversity of iminosugars at the C2 position, protected 2‐iodoiminoglycals, efficiently synthesized from sugar lactams, are subjected to mild palladium‐catalyzed cross‐coupling reactions. Successful aminocarbonylation, arylation, and phosphonylation provide a range of C2‐functionalized iminoglycals, which, once O‐deprotected, are tested as glycosidase inhibitors.
To vary the functionality of iminosugars at the C2 position, protected 2‐iodoiminoglycals in the D‐gluco, D‐galacto, and D‐xylo series are efficiently synthesized from sugar lactams. Their mild palladium‐catalyzed aminocarbonylation, arylation, and phosphonylation are successful and provide a range of C2‐functionalized iminoglycals in good yields. Two of these compounds are O‐deprotected to afford 1,2‐unsaturated iminosugars that prove to be modest inhibitors of glycosidases.
item.content:encoded:

Successful aminocarbonylation, arylation, and phosphonylation provide a range of C2-functionalized iminoglycals, which, once O-deprotected, are tested as glycosidase inhibitors.


To vary the functionality of iminosugars at the C2 position, protected 2-iodoiminoglycals in the D-gluco, D-galacto, and D-xylo series are efficiently synthesized from sugar lactams. Their mild palladium-catalyzed aminocarbonylation, arylation, and phosphonylation are successful and provide a range of C2-functionalized iminoglycals in good yields. Two of these compounds are O-deprotected to afford 1,2-unsaturated iminosugars that prove to be modest inhibitors of glycosidases.

item.title: Facilitating the Isolation of Polar Natural Products: Mild 1,1′‐Carbonyldiimidazole‐Enabled Method for Derivatization of Acids and Alcohols
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, EarlyView.
item.dc:description:
In this work, 1,1′‐carbonyldiimidazole, a relatively inexpensive reagent with inherently low toxicity, is utilized to activate polar natural products containing carboxylic acids and alcohols to enable the formation of less polar species (N‐acylimidazoles and N‐acyloxymidazoles). These intermediates are readily converted into methyl esters and carbonates by treatment with methanol.
Many secondary metabolites containing carboxylic acid and alcohol functional groups are highly polar and can be difficult to purify and isolate from complex extracts obtained from natural sources. The conversion of these natural products to their corresponding alkyl esters/carbonates under mild conditions can simplify their purification and isolation. However, traditional derivatization methods have often relied on toxic and/ or corrosive reagents that can also lead to byproduct formation or epimerization in some instances. In this work, 1,1′‐carbonyldiimidazole, a relatively inexpensive reagent with inherently low toxicity, is utilized to activate polar natural products containing carboxylic acids and alcohols to enable the formation of less polar species (N‐acylimidazoles and N‐acyloxymidazoles). These intermediates are readily converted into methyl esters and carbonates by treatment with methanol. It is anticipated that this rather simple and versatile derivatization method can facilitate the efficient isolation of secondary metabolites bearing polar carboxylic acid and alcohol residues.

These intermediates are readily converted into methyl esters and carbonates by treatment with methanol.

It is anticipated that this rather simple and versatile derivatization method can facilitate the efficient isolation of secondary metabolites bearing polar carboxylic acid and alcohol residues.

item.source: Wiley-Online-Library: European Journal of Organic Chemistry: Table of Contents
item.title: Gold‐Catalyzed Synthesis of Substituted 4‐Pentafluorosulfanyl‐1,3‐Oxazoles
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, EarlyView.
item.dc:description:
The first synthesis of pentafluorosulfanylated oxazoles has been developed. They are prepared using a gold(I)‐catalyzed oxidative cyclization of SF5‐alkynes and nitriles.
This work reports the first synthesis of pentafluorosulfanylated oxazoles through a gold(I)‐catalyzed cyclization of SF5‐alkynes and nitriles. It describes 18 examples of 4‐SF5‐oxazoles with NMR yield ranging from 3% to 75%. While the isolation of the pure pentafluorosulfanylated oxazoles proves challenging, the fluorinated heterocycles can nonetheless be obtained in yields between 14% and 52%, opening the door for their use as a novel fluorine‐containing scaffold.
item.content:encoded:

This work reports the first synthesis of pentafluorosulfanylated oxazoles through a gold(I)-catalyzed cyclization of SF5-alkynes and nitriles. It describes 18 examples of 4-SF5-oxazoles with NMR yield ranging from 3% to 75%. While the isolation of the pure pentafluorosulfanylated oxazoles proves challenging, the fluorinated heterocycles can nonetheless be obtained in yields between 14% and 52%, opening the door for their use as a novel fluorine-containing scaffold.

item.source: Wiley-Online-Library: European Journal of Organic Chemistry: Table of Contents
item.title: Transition‐Metal‐Free Alkynylthiolation of Tertiary α‐Carbonyl Bromides
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, Accepted Article.
item.dc:description: Herein, we report a transition‐metal‐free alkynylthiolation of tertiary α‐carbonyl bromides with 1,2,3‐thiadiazoles. Those reactions involve the in‐situ generation of alkynylthiolate anions from 1,2,3‐thiadiazoles in the presence of a base and then their halogenophilic nucleophilic substitution (SN2X) reactions. The exceptionally mild reaction conditions, broad substrate scope, and excellent functional group tolerance highlight the utility of this method to prepare privileged motifs from readily available 1,2,3‐thiadiazoles and tertiary α‐carbonyl bromides feedstocks. Gram‐scale reaction and diverse synthetic transformations convincingly demonstrate the synthetic potential of this method.

The exceptionally mild reaction conditions, broad substrate scope, and excellent functional group tolerance highlight the utility of this method to prepare privileged motifs from readily available 1,2,3-thiadiazoles and tertiary α-carbonyl bromides feedstocks. Gram-scale reaction and diverse synthetic transformations convincingly demonstrate the synthetic potential of this method.

item.title: Rhodium‐Catalyzed (3+3) Cascade Cyclization of Diazobarbiturates with 2H‐Azirines for the Diastereoselective Construction of Spirooxazinopyrimidinediones
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, EarlyView.
item.dc:description:
Under the catalysis of Rh2(esp)2 (10 mol%) and BINAP (20 mol%) in 1,2‐dichloroethane at 80 °C, a (3+3) cascade cyclization between diazobarbiturates and 2H‐azirines proceeds smoothly, yielding spirooxazinopyrimidinediones in 24–92% yield with >20:1 diastereoselectivity. The chemical structure of one compound has been confirmed by X‐ray diffraction analysis, and the others are suggested by inference.

The chemical structure of one compound has been confirmed by X‐ray diffraction analysis, and the others are suggested by inference.

The chemical structure of one compound has been confirmed by X-ray diffraction analysis, and the others are suggested by inference.

item.title: Photocatalyst‐ and Oxidant‐Free Photoinduced Radical Cascade for the Synthesis of Difluoromethylated Dihydroisoquinolones from N‐Allylbenzamides with a Difluoromethyl Phenoxathiinium Salt
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, EarlyView.
item.dc:description:
A photoinduced radical cascade that does not require a photocatalyst or an oxidant has been developed for the convenient synthesis of difluoromethylated dihydroisoquinolones by the use of a difluoromethyl phenoxathiinium salt. The reaction features mild reaction conditions, broad substrate scope, high yields, and good functional‐group tolerance.
A mild photocatalyst‐ and oxidant‐free photoinduced reaction for the convenient synthesis of difluoromethylated dihydroisoquinolones from N‐allylbenzamides with a difluoromethyl phenoxathiinium salt (CF2H‐PXT+) is presented, which involves a radical difluoromethylation/cyclization cascade process with broad substrate scope and good functional‐group tolerance. Using this method, a broad range of N‐allylbenzamides are successfully converted to the desired difluoromethylated dihydroisoquinolones in good to high yields.
item.content:encoded:

The reaction features mild reaction conditions, broad substrate scope, high yields, and good functional-group tolerance.


A mild photocatalyst- and oxidant-free photoinduced reaction for the convenient synthesis of difluoromethylated dihydroisoquinolones from N-allylbenzamides with a difluoromethyl phenoxathiinium salt (CF2H-PXT+) is presented, which involves a radical difluoromethylation/cyclization cascade process with broad substrate scope and good functional-group tolerance. Using this method, a broad range of N-allylbenzamides are successfully converted to the desired difluoromethylated dihydroisoquinolones in good to high yields.

item.source: Wiley-Online-Library: European Journal of Organic Chemistry: Table of Contents
item.title: Visible‐Light‐Induced C─S Bond Formation Catalyzed by the Organic Photocatalyst Eosin Y
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, EarlyView.
item.dc:description:
In recent years, the formation of C─S bonds promoted by organic photosensitizer eosin Y under visible light has attracted great interest and attention among chemists. This article reviews the research results on the formation of C─S bond promoted by organic photocatalyst eosin Y under visible light since 2015, and discusses representative examples and reaction mechanisms.
The development of green and efficient C─S bond formation methods has received significant attention from synthetic chemists because the C─S bonds widely occurs in many important drugs and natural biological compounds. In recent years, photochemical organic conversion promoted by visible light has attracted the interest of many organic chemists. Compared with the traditional methods, visible light as the photoredox catalysis of renewable energy has been proved to be a mild and powerful tool that can promote the activation of organic molecules through the single electron transfer process. Therefore, this strategy has been widely applied in the formation of C─C and C─heteroatom bonds. This article reviews the research results on the formation of carbon sulfur bond promoted by organic photocatalyst Eosin Y under visible light in recent years, and discusses representative examples and reaction mechanisms.

item.title: ONO–Cobalt Catalyzed Reduction of Sulfoxides to Sulfides with Poly(methylhydrosiloxane) as the Deoxygenation Reagent
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, EarlyView.
item.dc:description:
A highly efficient cobalt‐catalyzed reduction of sulfoxides to sulfides is developed with poly(methylhydrosiloxane) (PMHS) as the reductant. Under optimized conditions, turnover numbers of up to 7200 are observed.
Herein the cobalt‐catalyzed reduction of sulfoxides to sulfides with a well‐defined tridentate tetrahydroquinolin‐8‐one‐2‐carboxamide (ONO)–cobalt complex as the precatalyst is reported. Inexpensive poly(methylhydrosiloxane) (PMHS) is used as the reductant. This newly developed catalytic system is applied successfully to a broad range of substrates, including diaryl, aryl alkyl, and dialkyl sulfoxides as well as cyclic sulfoxides, and accordingly delivered diverse sulfides in high yields. Importantly, turnover numbers up to 7200 are achieved with this protocol.

item.title: Electrochemical gem‐Bisarylation of Hydrazone: Access to Bis(indolyl)methane
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, EarlyView.
item.dc:description:
An electrochemical organic method for the direct synthesis of bis(indolyl)methane (BIM) derivatives is presented, with the reaction of hydrazones and indoles. This electrochemical approach, characterized by simple and mild reaction conditions, provides an operationally straightforward and practically applicable route to valuable indole derivatives, utilizing readily available raw materials.
An electrochemical organic method for the direct synthesis of bis(indolyl)methane (BIM) derivatives is presented, with the reaction of hydrazones and indoles. This developed approach is effective for aliphatic, aromatic, and heteroaromatic aldehydes, which react with a range of electron‐rich and electron‐poor indoles to produce the desired BIMs in good to excellent yields. Additionally, a potential antiobesity drug is also successfully synthesized with various indole derivatives under the influence of an electric current, and the transformation of BIMs demonstrates the application potential of this protocol.

item.source: Wiley-Online-Library: European Journal of Organic Chemistry: Table of Contents
item.title: Ecofriendly Borylation of Allylic Acetates via Nickel‐Catalyzed Dual‐Role Base Activation
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, EarlyView.
item.dc:description:
A glovebox‐free, scalable Ni‐catalyzed borylation of allylic acetates using cost‐effective reagents and a recyclable ligand is presented. The reaction proceeds in EtOAc with a dual‐role base, delivering a diverse range of allylic boronates in yields up to 97%.
Allylic boronates are valuable synthons in organic chemistry, making the development of efficient and sustainable preparation methods highly desirable. A nickel‐catalyzed borylation of unactivated allylic acetates using a recyclable N‐donor ligand system in ethyl acetate is reported. The method employs an innovative dual‐role base that simultaneously activates diboron reagents and reduces air‐stable NiBr2, eliminating the need for external reductants. The approach shows excellent compatibility across a diverse array of substrates, delivering the desired products with isolated yields up to 97%. Its operational simplicity is evidenced by glovebox‐free conditions and successful multigram‐scale implementation (13 mmol scale, yields up to 95%), underscoring the method's practicality as a ecofriendly alternative to conventional allylic borylation.
item.content:encoded:

item.title: Photoredox Decarboxylative 3‐Fluoroallylation of α‐Amino Acids
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, EarlyView.
item.dc:description:
An efficient, photocatalytic method for the decarboxylative 3‐fluoroallylation of α‐amino acids has been developed to produce fluorinated homoallylamines. A broad reaction scope is reported, including the use of dipeptides and different protecting groups on nitrogen. Further manipulation of products suggests the potential for late‐stage functionalization toward the synthesis of monofluoroalkene‐containing molecules.
The photocatalytic decarboxylation of α‐amino acids is an effective route to α‐aminoalkyl radicals, which is also amenable to the derivatization of peptides through selective CC bond formation at the C‐terminus. It is reported that, in the presence of an iridium photocatalyst, allylic difluorides are suitable radical traps to capture α‐aminoalkyl radicals produced from α‐amino acids, ultimately amounting to a defluorinative 3‐fluoroallylation reaction. The catalytic system is applied to the derivatization of a wide breadth of N‐protected amino acids and dipeptides in high yields, and the transformation displays great functional group tolerance. α‐Amino acids of all substitution levels at the α‐carbon led to the desired products in high yields. Post‐functionalization of the monofluoroalkene‐containing products reveals the potential to attain fluorine‐containing organic compounds of greater complexity.
item.content:encoded:

A broad reaction scope is reported, including the use of dipeptides and different protecting groups on nitrogen. Further manipulation of products suggests the potential for late-stage functionalization toward the synthesis of monofluoroalkene-containing molecules.


The photocatalytic decarboxylation of α-amino acids is an effective route to α-aminoalkyl radicals, which is also amenable to the derivatization of peptides through selective CC bond formation at the C-terminus. It is reported that, in the presence of an iridium photocatalyst, allylic difluorides are suitable radical traps to capture α-aminoalkyl radicals produced from α-amino acids, ultimately amounting to a defluorinative 3-fluoroallylation reaction. The catalytic system is applied to the derivatization of a wide breadth of N-protected amino acids and dipeptides in high yields, and the transformation displays great functional group tolerance. α-Amino acids of all substitution levels at the α-carbon led to the desired products in high yields. Post-functionalization of the monofluoroalkene-containing products reveals the potential to attain fluorine-containing organic compounds of greater complexity.

item.title: Facile Synthesis of 5‐Halo‐1,2,3‐Triazole‐Fused Benzotricyclic Frameworks from 1‐(ω‐Azidoalkyl)‐2‐(2,2‐Dihalovinyl)Arenes and their Application in Fluorescent Triazole Derivatives
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, EarlyView.
item.dc:description:
5‐halo‐1,2,3‐triazole‐fused tricyclic compounds, prepared from 1‐(ω‐azidoalkyl)‐2‐(2,2‐dihalovinyl)arenes, undergo Pd‐catalyzed cross‐coupling with 2‐nitrobenzeneboronic acids, followed by triphenylphosphine treatment, yielding diverse fluorescent pentacyclic compounds incorporating triazole rings.
By heating 1‐(ω‐azidoalkyl)‐2‐(2,2‐dihalovinyl)arenes in DMF, intramolecular Huisgen cycloaddition between the azido group and the 1,1‐dihalovinyl moiety proceeds smoothly to afford 5‐halo‐1,2,3‐triazole‐fused tricyclic benzocondensed compounds. Leveraging the remaining halogen groups, the carbon chain extension via the Mizoroki–Heck or Suzuki–Miyaura coupling reactions, followed by an intramolecular Friedel–Crafts reaction, furnish polycyclic systems that incorporate fused triazole rings. Furthermore, the transformation of the halogen groups into the 2‐nitrobenzene derivatives via Suzuki–Miyaura cross‐coupling, followed by a Cadogan reaction using triphenylphosphine, provides a series of fluorescent pentacyclic compounds.

By heating 1-(ω-azidoalkyl)-2-(2,2-dihalovinyl)arenes in DMF, intramolecular Huisgen cycloaddition between the azido group and the 1,1-dihalovinyl moiety proceeds smoothly to afford 5-halo-1,2,3-triazole-fused tricyclic benzocondensed compounds. Furthermore, the transformation of the halogen groups into the 2-nitrobenzene derivatives via Suzuki–Miyaura cross-coupling, followed by a Cadogan reaction using triphenylphosphine, provides a series of fluorescent pentacyclic compounds.

item.dc:title: Facile Synthesis of 5‐Halo‐1,2,3‐Triazole‐Fused Benzotricyclic Frameworks from 1‐(ω‐Azidoalkyl)‐2‐(2,2‐Dihalovinyl)Arenes and their Application in Fluorescent Triazole Derivatives

item.source: Wiley-Online-Library: European Journal of Organic Chemistry: Table of Contents
item.title: Decarboxylative Michael Additions of Substituted Malonic Acid Half‐Oxyesters to Methylidene Malonates
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, EarlyView.
item.dc:description:
Substituted malonic acid half oxyesters reacted with alkylidene malonates in a fast, efficient decarboxylative Michael addition, delivering adducts in high yields. The reaction occurred in bulk solvent, open to air, needing only a weak amine base as an organocatalyst to drive a mechanism involving addition prior to decarboxylation.
Decarboxylative Michael additions between substituted malonic acids half oxyesters (SMAHOs) and methylidene malonates have been achieved using either a catalytic amount of a weak base such as N‐methyl‐morpholine or di‐iso‐propylamine in a refluxing solvent. This transformation occurs under practical conditions (bulk solvent and open to air) and can be performed with various SMAHOs and methylidene malonates, in yields ranging from 22 to 89%. Nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR), studies support the occurrence of a Michael addition pre‐decarboxylation mechanism.

item.title: Luminescent Click‐Pyrenyl Nucleosides: as Novel Building Blocks for Nucleic Acids: Synthesis, Photophysics, Confocal Microscopy Studies, and Oligonucleotide Conjugation
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, EarlyView.
item.dc:description:
Dinucleoside phosphate analogues with a luminescent pyrenyl‐triazole‐N‐(triazole)2 linker substituting the natural phosphodiester linkage are obtained by the CuAAC reaction. Representative dinucleoside is conjugated to the deoxyribonucleotide 5’‐d(TTT CTT TCC CTC)‐3′. The resulting conjugate remains capable of forming a stable B‐type DNA duplex with a complementary oligonucleotide strand.
Three artificial dinucleoside phosphate analogues with a pyrenyl‐triazole‐N‐(triazole)2 linker substituting the natural phosphodiester linkage are reported. These novel compounds are prepared by the copper‐catalyzed azide alkyne cycloaddition reaction (CuAAC) of a suitably designed pyrenyl‐dialkyne with 3′‐azido thymidine and 5′‐azido adenosine building blocks, respectively. The pyrenyl chromophore confers luminescent properties to these dinucleosides. In diluted dichloromethane (DCM) and dimethyl sulfoxide (DMSO) solutions, the compounds show structured fluorescence emission in the blue region of the spectrum, while at higher concentrations or in the solid state, a featureless and broad excimer emission with λem ≈ 470 nm is observed. Studied compounds are devoid of anticancer activity against a panel of five human cancer cell lines as well as in noncancerous human microvascular endothelial cells. The demonstrated lack of toxicity in combination with excimer emission allows for the assessment of dinucleoside distribution inside cancer Michigan cancer foundation (MCF)‐7 cells with confocal luminescence microscopy. Compounds exhibit affinity to membranous structures as well as accumulate in the perinuclear region of the cells. Moreover, a selected dinucleoside is successfully conjugated to the deoxyribonucleotide 5′‐d(TTT CTT TCC CTC)‐3′. The resulting conjugate remains capable of forming a stable B‐type DNA duplex with a complementary oligonucleotide strand.

item.title: Formal Higher‐Order [8 + 3] Cycloaddition of Azaheptafulvenes with Donor–Acceptor Cyclopropanes
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, EarlyView.
item.dc:description:
A formal higher‐order [8+3] cycloaddition of azaheptafulvenes with donor–acceptor cyclopropanes is developed to access cyclohepta[b]pyridines, exhibiting broad substrate accommodation. The nucleophilic cyclopropane ring opening is a key process of the [8+3] cycloaddition, and most probably proceeds via a “exploded” SN2 transition state with a high degree of carbocation character.
Cyclohepta[b]pyridine derivatives have attracted significant attention owing to their unique bioactivities. Herein, the authors describe an efficient method to access various cyclohepta[b]pyridine derivatives through formal higher‐order [8 + 3] cycloaddition of azaheptafulvenes with donor–acceptor cyclopropanes catalyzed by Yb(OTf)3. This method exhibits broad substrate accommodation and gives the corresponding products in high yields and selectivity.

item.title: Identifying the True Catalyst: A Mn(II) Salt versus Mn(II) Complexes in Epoxidation with m‐Chloroperbenzoic Acid
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, EarlyView.
item.dc:description:
During the investigation of the reactivity of three Mn complexes, Mn(ClO4)2 shows higher reactivity toward styrene epoxidation, indicating that ligand coordination inhibits the reactivity of the manganese center. Raman spectroscopy provides mechanistic insight: monitoring alkene epoxidation and consumption of the oxidant over time, the true nature of the active catalyst is revealed, and competition reactions are discovered.
The oxidant meta‐chloroperbenzoic acid (m‐CPBA) is used widely for the epoxidation of alkenes, yet its efficiency is often limited under ambient conditions. This study investigates the catalytic activity of a Mn(II) salt and mononuclear Mn(II) complexes, two of which are reported here for the first time, in the epoxidation of alkenes with m‐CPBA under ambient conditions. Time‐resolved Raman spectroscopy is used to monitor substrate conversion, oxidant consumption, and product formation. The data reveal that simple Mn(II) salts exhibit significantly higher catalytic activity than Mn(II) complexes, indicating that ligand coordination inhibits the reactivity of the manganese center. The catalytic efficiency of Mn(II) perchlorate is particularly notable, achieving near‐complete oxidation of styrene within minutes under mild conditions. Furthermore, epoxidation of a range of alkenes demonstrates that Mn(II) salts provide broad substrate scope and high selectivity. These findings suggest that simple Mn(II) salts can serve as highly efficient and cost‐effective catalysts in alkene epoxidations with m‐CPBA.

The oxidant meta-chloroperbenzoic acid (m-CPBA) is used widely for the epoxidation of alkenes, yet its efficiency is often limited under ambient conditions. This study investigates the catalytic activity of a Mn(II) salt and mononuclear Mn(II) complexes, two of which are reported here for the first time, in the epoxidation of alkenes with m-CPBA under ambient conditions. Furthermore, epoxidation of a range of alkenes demonstrates that Mn(II) salts provide broad substrate scope and high selectivity. These findings suggest that simple Mn(II) salts can serve as highly efficient and cost-effective catalysts in alkene epoxidations with m-CPBA.

item.title: Fluorinated Aminophosphonates and Aminophosphonic Acids: A Journey through Recent Advances
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, EarlyView.
item.dc:description:
Recent advances in the synthesis of fluorinated aminophosphonates and aminophosphonic acids are highlighted, with particular emphasis on regio‐, diastereo‐, and enantioselective methods that allow precise introduction of fluorine atoms.
This review aims to summarize the most recent developments in the chemistry of fluorinated aminophosphonates and aminophosphonic acids, with a particular focus on literature published since the turn of 2016/2017. Fluorinated derivatives of aminophosphonates and aminophosphonic acids represent a rapidly growing area of interest due to their unique chemical properties and potential applications in various fields, including medicinal and agricultural chemistry. In this work, special emphasis is placed on highlighting the most significant reports concerning selective and efficient synthetic methodologies for these compounds. Particular attention is given to strategies that offer high yields, regio‐ or stereoselectivity, and operational simplicity, including direct fluorination, addition reactions, as well as catalytic and radical processes. Additionally, the review discusses the potential practical applications of these fluorinated derivatives, such as their roles as enzyme inhibitors, bioisosteres of amino acids, and potential pharmaceuticals.

item.title: Upcycling Food Waste: Ursolic Acid as Sustainable Feedstock
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, EarlyView.
item.dc:description:
This study presents a sustainable strategy to access 24 ursane‐type natural products from ursolic acid, derived from apple pomace waste. The method enables short syntheses (1–12 steps) with high yields (up to 98%). By upcycling food waste into valuable bioactive compounds, this work exemplifies green chemistry and supports circular economy principles in natural product synthesis.
Herein, a sustainable strategy to access the ursane class of natural products is presented. The complexity‐controlling synthesis approach employs ursolic acid—readily obtained from apple pomace, a waste product of apple juice production—as sustainable feedstock to access 24 natural products of the ursane family in short synthetic sequences (1–12 steps) and good yields (up to 98%).

item.title: Aggregation‐Induced Asymmetric Synthesis of 2,3‐Dihydrobenzofurans by [4 + 1] Annulation with Substituted Salicyl N‐Phosphonyl Imines
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, EarlyView.
item.dc:description:
An aggregation‐induced asymmetric synthesis involving the [4 + 1] annulation of salicyl N‐phosphonyl imines with a sulfur ylide occurred with tunable diastereoselectivity depending on the cosolvent ratio of THF/EtOH. Aggregation‐induced emission , aggregation‐induced polarization, and dynamic light scattering experiments indicate that the stereocontrol observed in the reaction is due to the formation of chiral aggregates.
The aggregation‐induced asymmetric synthesis (AIAS) of trans‐2,3‐dihydrobenzofuran compounds is achieved via the reaction of salicyl N‐phosphonyl imines with sulfur ylide. This transformation proceeds through a [4 + 1] annulation pathway, affording products in good to excellent yields with tunable diastereoselectivities. By employing various THF/EtOH cosolvent systems in conjunction with GAP chemistry, the conventional aggregation cosolvent systems are shown to play a crucial role in enhancing diastereoselectivity and modulating aggregate formation. This is supported by studies involving aggregation‐induced emission, aggregation‐induced polarization, and dynamic light scattering. The developed protocol provides a practical and versatile synthetic approach to 2,3‐dihydrobenzofuran scaffolds, highlighting the utility of AIAS as a powerful strategy for achieving stereocontrol.
item.content:encoded:

Aggregation-induced emission , aggregation-induced polarization, and dynamic light scattering experiments indicate that the stereocontrol observed in the reaction is due to the formation of chiral aggregates.


The aggregation-induced asymmetric synthesis (AIAS) of trans-2,3-dihydrobenzofuran compounds is achieved via the reaction of salicyl N-phosphonyl imines with sulfur ylide. This transformation proceeds through a [4 + 1] annulation pathway, affording products in good to excellent yields with tunable diastereoselectivities. By employing various THF/EtOH cosolvent systems in conjunction with GAP chemistry, the conventional aggregation cosolvent systems are shown to play a crucial role in enhancing diastereoselectivity and modulating aggregate formation. This is supported by studies involving aggregation-induced emission, aggregation-induced polarization, and dynamic light scattering. The developed protocol provides a practical and versatile synthetic approach to 2,3-dihydrobenzofuran scaffolds, highlighting the utility of AIAS as a powerful strategy for achieving stereocontrol.

item.title: Reaction of Nitrones with Phosphinylallenes: DFT Mechanistic Investigations
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, EarlyView.
item.dc:description:
The mechanism of the reaction between phosphinylallenes and nitrones is investigated by DFT calculations to elucidate the overall pathway and the stereochemical outcome. The initial (3+2) cycloaddition delivers an unstable isoxazolidine ylidene intermediate, spontaneously rearranging to the 4‐phosphinylpyrrolidin‐3‐one via a radical pathway. This study describes the successive reaction steps and shows how conformational and steric effects influence selectivity.
The reaction between phosphinylallenes and nitrones efficiently leads to 4‐phosphinylpyrrolidin‐3‐ones. The mechanism of this transformation is investigated theoretically to elucidate the overall pathway and the stereochemical outcome. The process begins with a (3+2) cycloaddition between the nitrone and the allene, delivering an isoxazolidine ylidene intermediate. This intermediate has never been isolated; it spontaneously rearranges to the final 4‐phosphinylpyrrolidin‐3‐one via homolytic cleavage of the NO bond, followed by rotation and CN recombination of the biradical intermediate. The computational results provide valuable insights for achieving diastereo‐ and enantioselective synthesis of 4‐phosphinylpyrrolidin‐3‐ones through careful selection of substituents on the nitrone and allene.
item.content:encoded:

This study describes the successive reaction steps and shows how conformational and steric effects influence selectivity.


The reaction between phosphinylallenes and nitrones efficiently leads to 4-phosphinylpyrrolidin-3-ones. The mechanism of this transformation is investigated theoretically to elucidate the overall pathway and the stereochemical outcome. item.title: Selective Ruthenium‐Catalyzed Photoredox α‐C(sp3)–H Alkynylation of Cyclic Amines under Visible Light
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, EarlyView.
item.dc:description:
A visible‐light‐induced α‐C(sp3)–H alkynylation of cyclic amines is developed using [Ru(bpy)3]Cl2·6H2O as a photocatalyst and 1‐bromoalkynes as coupling partners. The method enables the efficient synthesis of α‐aminoalkynes with moderate to excellent yields. Mechanistic studies suggest a radical pathway initiated by single‐electron transfer, and the protocol is scalable under mild photoredox conditions.
A direct visible‐light α‐C(sp3)–H bond alkynylation of N‐aryl pyrrolidine derivatives with 1‐bromoalkynes has been developed, enabling the synthesis of propargylic amines. This transformation utilizes [Ru(bpy)3]Cl2·6H2O as a photocatalyst, driven by blue LED (455 nm) irradiation. Detailed mechanistic studies and cyclic voltammetry support the proposed reaction pathway, where the C(sp3)–C(sp) bond formation occurs via the oxidation of α‐amino radicals, followed by a radical coupling with 1‐bromoalkynes. This approach offers a straightforward, efficient, and selective method for synthesizing a wide range of cyclic α‐aminoalkynes, yielding moderate to good yields.
item.content:encoded:
A visible-light-induced α-C(sp3)–H alkynylation of cyclic amines is developed using [Ru(bpy)3]Cl2·6H2O as a photocatalyst and 1-bromoalkynes as coupling partners. The method enables the efficient synthesis of α-aminoalkynes with moderate to excellent yields. Mechanistic studies suggest a radical pathway initiated by single-electron transfer, and the protocol is scalable under mild photoredox conditions.


A direct visible-light α-C(sp 3)–H bond alkynylation of N-aryl pyrrolidine derivatives with 1-bromoalkynes has been developed, enabling the synthesis of propargylic amines. This transformation utilizes [Ru(bpy)3]Cl2·6H2O as a photocatalyst, driven by blue LED (455 nm) irradiation. Detailed mechanistic studies and cyclic voltammetry support the proposed reaction pathway, where the C(sp 3)–C(sp) bond formation occurs via the oxidation of α-amino radicals, followed by a radical coupling with 1-bromoalkynes. This approach offers a straightforward, efficient, and selective method for synthesizing a wide range of cyclic α-aminoalkynes, yielding moderate to good yields.

item.dc:title: Selective Ruthenium‐Catalyzed Photoredox α‐C(sp3)–H Alkynylation of Cyclic Amines under Visible Light

item.title: Photoredox‐Catalyzed Selective Dioxygenation of gem‐Difluorocyclopropanes to Generate α,α‐Difluorinated‐1,3‐diethers
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, EarlyView.
item.dc:description:
In this study, we report a mild and efficient photoredox‐catalyzed dioxygenation of gem‐difluorocyclopropanes with alcohols, preserving both fluorine atoms and resulting in the formation of α,α‐difluorinated‐1,3‐diethers. This approach is operationally simple, utilizes inexpensive and widely available reagents, and showcases broad functional group compatibility. Preliminary mechanistic investigations point to a radical‐mediated mechanism, which involves a concerted SN2‐like ring‐opening functionalization.
Abstract gem‐Difluorocyclopropanes are valuable synthetic intermediates in organofluorine chemistry; however, their reactivity often involves intermediates prone to fluorine elimination, leading to monofluorinated products. Here, we present a photoredox‐catalyzed dioxygenation of gem‐difluorocyclopropanes with alcohols, which retains both fluorine atoms and yields α,α‐difluorinated‐1,3‐diethers. This method is operationally simple, employs inexpensive and standard reagents, and demonstrates broad functional group tolerance. The reaction is scalable, enabling the use of the gem‐difluorocyclopropane motif as a masked precursor for α,α‐difluorinated‐1,3‐diethers in synthetic sequences. Preliminary mechanistic studies suggest a radical‐mediated process involving concerted SN2‐like ring‐opening functionalization.
item.content:encoded:
In this study, we report a mild and efficient photoredox-catalyzed dioxygenation of gem-difluorocyclopropanes with alcohols, preserving both fluorine atoms and resulting in the formation of α,α-difluorinated-1,3-diethers. This approach is operationally simple, utilizes inexpensive and widely available reagents, and showcases broad functional group compatibility. Preliminary mechanistic investigations point to a radical-mediated mechanism, which involves a concerted SN2-like ring-opening functionalization.


Abstract

gem-Difluorocyclopropanes are valuable synthetic intermediates in organofluorine chemistry; however, their reactivity often involves intermediates prone to fluorine elimination, leading to monofluorinated products. Here, we present a photoredox-catalyzed dioxygenation of gem-difluorocyclopropanes with alcohols, which retains both fluorine atoms and yields α,α-difluorinated-1,3-diethers. This method is operationally simple, employs inexpensive and standard reagents, and demonstrates broad functional group tolerance. The reaction is scalable, enabling the use of the gem-difluorocyclopropane motif as a masked precursor for α,α-difluorinated-1,3-diethers in synthetic sequences. Preliminary mechanistic studies suggest a radical-mediated process involving concerted SN2-like ring-opening functionalization.

item.dc:title: Photoredox‐Catalyzed Selective Dioxygenation of gem‐Difluorocyclopropanes to Generate α,α‐Difluorinated‐1,3‐diethers

item.title: Comparative Optoelectronic Properties of Rhodanine N‐Glucoside‐Derived Conjugated Systems
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, EarlyView.
item.dc:description:
Four rhodanine‐derived conjugated systems, incorporating N,N‐diphenylamine and extended with furan or thiophene, undergo glycosylation at the rhodanine nitrogen atom with yields up to 49% in 5 steps. The optoelectronic properties remain unaffected by the presence of glucose. Devices fabricated using the synthesized materials blended with PC71BM in a bulk heterojunction configuration clearly exhibit a photovoltaic effect.
Rhodanine‐derived conjugated systems, incorporating N,N‐diphenylamine and extended with either furan or thiophene, are glycosylated through the nitrogen atom of the rhodanine ring. The optoelectronic properties of these dyes are investigated, revealing that the presence of glucose does not negatively impact their beneficial properties. Additionally, solar cells are built using these systems, demonstrating their photovoltaic capabilities.
item.content:encoded:
Four rhodanine-derived conjugated systems, incorporating N,N-diphenylamine and extended with furan or thiophene, undergo glycosylation at the rhodanine nitrogen atom with yields up to 49% in 5 steps. The optoelectronic properties remain unaffected by the presence of glucose. Devices fabricated using the synthesized materials blended with PC71BM in a bulk heterojunction configuration clearly exhibit a photovoltaic effect.

Additionally, solar cells are built using these systems, demonstrating their photovoltaic capabilities.

item.source: Wiley-Online-Library: European Journal of Organic Chemistry: Table of Contents
item.title: C4‐Regioselective Dearomatization of Quinolinium Salts via Morita‐Baylis‐Hillman Reaction
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, Accepted Article.
item.dc:description: An intermolecular Morita‐Baylis‐Hillman reaction employing N‐benzylquinolinium salts as electrophiles was developed. The reaction proceeds through a C4‐selective dearomatization of the quinolinium substrate, contrary to the C2‐regioselectivity that was observed in our previous report on a similar process. The switch in the regioselectivity was accomplished through the change of the counterion in the quinolinium salt to PF6– and the alteration of the reaction conditions, such as the application of a different catalyst (DABCO). The reaction allows for the preparation of functional group‐rich products featuring the important 1,4‐dihydroquinoline scaffold, complementing the earlier method which provides the corresponding 1,2‐dihydroquinoline counterparts. The developed reaction is compatible with a range of substrates that also encompasses acridinium salts.
item.content:encoded: An intermolecular Morita-Baylis-Hillman reaction employing N-benzylquinolinium salts as electrophiles was developed. The reaction proceeds through a C4-selective dearomatization of the quinolinium substrate, contrary to the C2-regioselectivity that was observed in our previous report on a similar process. The switch in the regioselectivity was accomplished through the change of the counterion in the quinolinium salt to PF6– and the alteration of the reaction conditions, such as the application of a different catalyst (DABCO). The reaction allows for the preparation of functional group-rich products featuring the important 1,4-dihydroquinoline scaffold, complementing the earlier method which provides the corresponding 1,2-dihydroquinoline counterparts. The developed reaction is compatible with a range of substrates that also encompasses acridinium salts.

item.title: Rational Control of C–N Axial Chirality in Bis‐pentatomic N‐Pyrazolyl Maleimides through an Experimental and Computational Approach
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, Accepted Article.
item.dc:description: The control of axial chirality in atropisomeric compounds has gained significant importance in modern synthetic chemistry due to their relevance in the design of materials and biologically active molecules. We investigated the configurational stability of a series of axially chiral N‐pyrazolyl maleimides through a combined theoretical and experimental approach. Initially, DFT computations were used to predict the corresponding barriers to enantiomerisation of multiple derivatives holding a large variety of substituents at different positions of both heterocyclic nuclei on either side of the C–N bond. Then, the predicted barriers were validated through dynamic chiral HPLC analysis, providing experimental evidence for the configurational stability of these challenging bis‐pentatomic C–N atropisomers. Compounds featuring a 1‐N‐t‐butyl group as well as a C‐4‐substituent on the aminopyrazole ring exhibited high barriers to enantiomerisation, confirming their potential as a new family of atropisomerically stable heterocyclic compounds. Variation of the substitution on the maleimide nucleus had no significant influence on the overall configurational stability. The good correlation between theoretical predictions and experimental findings, highlights the strength of the DFT computations in predicting configurational stability of chiral N‐pyrazolyl maleimides, providing a predictive framework for designing new atropisomeric N‐pyrazolyl maleimides with restricted rotation around the C–N bond.
item.content:encoded: The control of axial chirality in atropisomeric compounds has gained significant importance in modern synthetic chemistry due to their relevance in the design of materials and biologically active molecules. Initially, DFT computations were used to predict the corresponding barriers to enantiomerisation of multiple derivatives holding a large variety of substituents at different positions of both heterocyclic nuclei on either side of the C–N bond. Then, the predicted barriers were validated through dynamic chiral HPLC analysis, providing experimental evidence for the configurational stability of these challenging bis-pentatomic C–N atropisomers. Compounds featuring a 1-N-t-butyl group as well as a C-4-substituent on the aminopyrazole ring exhibited high barriers to enantiomerisation, confirming their potential as a new family of atropisomerically stable heterocyclic compounds. Variation of the substitution on the maleimide nucleus had no significant influence on the overall configurational stability. The good correlation between theoretical predictions and experimental findings, highlights the strength of the DFT computations in predicting configurational stability of chiral N-pyrazolyl maleimides, providing a predictive framework for designing new atropisomeric N-pyrazolyl maleimides with restricted rotation around the C–N bond.

item.dc:title: Rational Control of C–N Axial Chirality in Bis‐pentatomic N‐Pyrazolyl Maleimides through an Experimental and Computational Approach

item.title: Molecular iodine‐mediated functionalization of α‐Carbonyl Sulfoxonium ylides with Thiocyanates, Xanthates and Dithiocarbamates
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, Accepted Article.
item.dc:description: In this work, we present a straightforward, rapid, and cost‐effective protocol for synthesizing three distinct classes of α‐functionalized sulfoxonium ylides—α‐xanthate, α‐thiocyanate, and α‐dithiocarbamate—via molecular iodine‐mediated reactions. This method demonstrates broad substrate tolerance, including heterocycles and steroids, delivering 25 examples with yields of up to 83%. Experimental studies revealed that iodine reacts with xanthates to form disulfides, which subsequently act as electrophiles for nucleophilic attack by the ylide.

This method demonstrates broad substrate tolerance, including heterocycles and steroids, delivering 25 examples with yields of up to 83%. Experimental studies revealed that iodine reacts with xanthates to form disulfides, which subsequently act as electrophiles for nucleophilic attack by the ylide.

item.title: A Multicomponent aza‐Prins Strategy for the Diastereoselective Synthesis of Piperidine‐Fused Dihydroquinazolinones
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, EarlyView.
item.dc:description:
Herein, a novel multicomponent aza‐Prins strategy is presented to synthesize decorated piperidine‐fused dihydroquinazolinones. A bifunctional aldehyde is reacted with a homoallylic amine in a one‐pot cascade fashion to afford a highly reactive N‐acyliminium ion. By the addition of various nucleophiles, 4‐substituted piperidines can be obtained with high levels of diastereoselectivity.
Dihydroquinazolinones (DHQs) and piperidines are widely acknowledged as privileged structures and are of significant interest for the development of new drug candidates. Herein, a novel aza‐Prins strategy is presented for the synthesis of piperidine‐fused DHQs through a domino multicomponent reaction. Homoallylic ammonium halide salts are found to react with bifunctional aldehydes under acidic conditions to give halide‐substituted fused piperidines in a diastereoselective fashion. The reaction can be extended to the incorporation of alcohol nucleophiles via fine tuning of the reaction conditions. Finally, the utility of the substituted compounds is demonstrated by performing a variety of functionalization reactions on the scaffold.
item.content:encoded:
Herein, a novel multicomponent aza-Prins strategy is presented to synthesize decorated piperidine-fused dihydroquinazolinones. A bifunctional aldehyde is reacted with a homoallylic amine in a one-pot cascade fashion to afford a highly reactive N-acyliminium ion. By the addition of various nucleophiles, 4-substituted piperidines can be obtained with high levels of diastereoselectivity.


Dihydroquinazolinones (DHQs) and piperidines are widely acknowledged as privileged structures and are of significant interest for the development of new drug candidates. Herein, a novel aza-Prins strategy is presented for the synthesis of piperidine-fused DHQs through a domino multicomponent reaction. Homoallylic ammonium halide salts are found to react with bifunctional aldehydes under acidic conditions to give halide-substituted fused piperidines in a diastereoselective fashion. The reaction can be extended to the incorporation of alcohol nucleophiles via fine tuning of the reaction conditions. Finally, the utility of the substituted compounds is demonstrated by performing a variety of functionalization reactions on the scaffold.

item.title: Synthesis of Alkylated 1‐Aryl‐4,5‐Dimethylimidazolium‐Based Tunable Aryl Alkyl Ionic Liquids (TAAILs)
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, Volume 28, Issue 25, July 2, 2025.
item.dc:description:
New tunable aryl alkyl ionic liquids based on 2‐alkyl‐1‐aryl‐4,5‐dimethylimidazoles are synthesized using a deprotonation protocol to directly modify imidazoles without the need to rebuild the heterocyclic core. The viscosity, conductivity, and electrochemical stability of the ionic liquids are measured.
Imidazolium‐based ionic liquids are one of the most important classes of ionic liquids due to their low viscosity and multitude of possible modifications. The properties of imidazolium‐based ionic liquids are strongly influenced by their hydrogen bond interactions, especially due to the hydrogen atoms at the core of the imidazolium cation. Herein, a new class of tunable aryl alkyl ionic liquids based on 2‐alkyl‐1‐aryl‐4,5‐dimethylimidazoles is presented, which do not possess hydrogen atoms directly bound to the imidazolium core. They are synthesized by deprotonation of the corresponding imidazoles, avoiding the need to rebuild the imidazolium motif. Electron donating substituents at the aryl ring allow for the deprotonation at the C2‐position of the imidazole ring. All ionic liquids are fully characterized (1H, 13C, 19F‐NMR, EA) and their physical properties, including their viscosity, conductivity, and electrochemical stability, are examined.
item.content:encoded:
New tunable aryl alkyl ionic liquids based on 2-alkyl-1-aryl-4,5-dimethylimidazoles are synthesized using a deprotonation protocol to directly modify imidazoles without the need to rebuild the heterocyclic core. The viscosity, conductivity, and electrochemical stability of the ionic liquids are measured.

Herein, a new class of tunable aryl alkyl ionic liquids based on 2-alkyl-1-aryl-4,5-dimethylimidazoles is presented, which do not possess hydrogen atoms directly bound to the imidazolium core. Electron donating substituents at the aryl ring allow for the deprotonation at the C2-position of the imidazole ring. All ionic liquids are fully characterized (1H, 13C, 19F-NMR, EA) and their physical properties, including their viscosity, conductivity, and electrochemical stability, are examined.

item.title: Photoinduced Reaction of Diiodoperfluoroalkanes with Aromatic Compounds: Divergent Synthesis of Two Product Types
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, Volume 28, Issue 25, July 2, 2025.
item.dc:description:
Reactions of aromatic compounds with diiodoperfluoroalkanes are investigated, and it is found that different products can be synthesized depending on the reaction conditions and amounts of reagents. In particular, the reaction of 1,4‐diiodoperfluorobutane under UV irradiation provides unique cyclic perfluoroalkyl aromatic compounds.
Both UV‐light‐promoted and organic‐dye‐catalyzed visible light‐promoted reactions of diiodoperfluoroalkanes with an iodine substituent at both ends and substituted anilines are attempted. In the reactions with 1,6‐ and 1,8‐diiodoperfluoroalkanes in the presence of an excess amount of aniline, both ends of the iodide reacts to give a diamine, and the reaction with an excess amount of diiodide gives a monoiodide, in which one end of the diiodide has reacted with the aniline. In contrast, in the case of the 1,4‐diiodoperfluoroalkane, the UV reaction yields cyclization products in which both ends of the diiodine has reacted with the same aromatic ring, while the visible light reaction yields products in which only one end has reacted. Since synthetic examples of such cyclization products are limited, the reaction with various aromatic compounds is tried and it has been shown that it is effective for electron‐rich aromatic rings. The mechanism of these reactions is discussed and the importance of the redox potential of the iodides is pointed out.
item.content:encoded:

The mechanism of these reactions is discussed and the importance of the redox potential of the iodides is pointed out.

item.title: Unlocking Indazole Synthesis from α‐Diazo‐β‐Ketoesters via Aryne Trapping: A Streamlined Approach
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, Volume 28, Issue 25, July 2, 2025.
item.dc:description:
To address the growing demand to develop, beyond laboratory scale, more efficient, safer and ecofriendly, as well as scalable mechanochemical transformations, the direct synthesis of 1‐acyl‐1H‐indazoles via α‐diazo‐β‐ketoesters aryne trapping is reported. The results reveal the unexpected formation of N‐aryl‐1H‐indazoles and aryl benzoates, likely facilitated by a thia‐fries rearrangement. Density functional theory calculations elucidate the cycloaddition pathway and rationalize the formation of the various reaction products.
Indazoles are high‐value chemical building blocks used in medicinal chemistry and materials science for their distinct structural and functional features. This study details a [3 + 2]‐cycloaddition reaction between various aryl‐ketodiazoesters and ortho‐(trimethylsilyl)aryl triflates under mild conditions, leading predominantly to 1‐acyl‐1H‐indazoles. N‐aryl‐1H‐indazoles and aryl benzoates are also observed as other products. The reaction exhibits broad functional group tolerance and scalability, making it a valuable synthetic approach. Mechanistic insights, derived from control experiments and density functional theory calculations, elucidate the cycloaddition pathway and rationalize the formation of the products. Collectively, these findings underscore the method's potential for synthesizing complex indazole derivatives, which hold significant promises for applications in pharmaceutical development and advanced materials research.
item.content:encoded:
